output_examples.input: How do I set up Supabase Auth in my Next.js App Router project?

best_practices: Always use @supabase/ssr package for App Router integration instead of @supabase/auth-helpers-nextjs
Handle auth state in middleware for protected routes rather than in each page
Keep auth tokens on the server side; avoid exposing them unnecessarily to the client
anti_patterns: Do not use getSession in Server Components - use getUser instead for proper server-side validation
Do not manage auth tokens manually in localStorage; rely on Supabase's cookie-based sessions
Do not handle auth state in Client Components without using onAuthStateChange listener

faq.question: What is @supabase/ssr and why do I need it?
faq.answer: @supabase/ssr is the official Supabase package for Next.js App Router. It provides utilities for handling cookies, sessions, and client creation that work correctly with Next.js server/client boundary.

faq.question: How does auth middleware work in Next.js?
faq.answer: Auth middleware runs before requests hit your pages. It checks the session cookie, validates it with Supabase, and redirects unauthenticated users to login pages.

faq.question: Can I use Supabase Auth with Server Actions?
faq.answer: Yes. Server Actions run on the server and can use the Supabase client directly. This is ideal for sign up, sign in, and sign out operations.

faq.question: What is the difference between getSession and getUser?
faq.answer: getSession returns the session from the cookie but validates it client-side. getUser validates the session server-side by calling Supabase. Always use getUser in Server Components.

faq.question: How do I handle OAuth callbacks?
faq.answer: Create a route handler at /auth/callback that receives the code from Supabase, exchanges it for a session using supabase.auth.exchangeCodeForSession, and redirects the user.

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with the Pages Router?
faq.answer: No. This skill specifically covers App Router integration. For Pages Router, use @supabase/auth-helpers-nextjs instead.
